newsitem.title: USA: COMEX copper called to open firmer.
newsitem.headline: COMEX copper called to open firmer.

text.p: COMEX copper futures were called to open firmer Friday, with the a test of the eight-month high set last month still seen possible even though the market is again beginning to look overbought, analysts said.
Renewed tightness in the prompt market, shortcovering by funds, news of a rise in China's copper imports in the first quarter, and the expiry of the COMEX May options Friday were also cited.
COMEX May copper was called unchanged to up 0.2 cent from Thursday's close of 112.35 cents a lb after trading from 112.00 to 112.70 cents on ACCESS.
Resistance for May delivery was pegged around 114.00 cents, a level seen briefly in early March.

The May/July spread has widened sharply again this week to over 2.00 cents, from 1.00 cent in mid-April, while on the LME the cash-to-three months spread was back out around $200 a tonne from below $50 a tonne in mid-April.
LME warehouse copper stocks fell 1,550 tonnes Friday to 145,200 tonnes, while COMEX stocks rose 1,070 short tons Thursday to 51,251 short tons.
China imported 18,954 tonnes of unrefined copper and copper anodes in the first quarter 1997, up 38.7 percent on the same period last year, according to Chinese Customes Dept data.
